entry.title: FSLabs Updates A321ceo and A321neo for MSFS 2020/2024
entry.summary: Sim: FS24. FSLabs has recently issued an update to their A321ceo and newly released A321neo for Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020 and 2024, bringing system improvements, model updates, sound enhancements, and more. Update v11.0.1.306 improves logging and error reporting, brings several improvements to the systems, adds wingflex in interior views, removes rubber marks from the flap textures, brings a complete rework of the ground roll, landing, and take-off sounds, and much more. The full changelog follows below: AOC Service: Systems Improvements: Model Updates: Sound Enhancements: ATSU Updates: Furthermore, FSLabs has added a free hardware interface for Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020 and 2024, bringing seamless integration between their two products and selected high-end hardware, starting with full support for the Skalarki product line. From the mini overhead panel to the DCDU, the interface allows plug-and-play functionality, aiming to deliver an immersive and highly authentic experience. It can be seen live and in action at FlightSimExpo 2025 at Skalarkiâs booth (stand 116). They conclude the blog post on the update with a brief progress update on the PWs, which is said to be coming soon, and they have been hard at work at properly integrating it, from its very unique âwhale-likeâ sound to how it performs and flies, being more than just a different 3D model. The update is only available on their experimental channel for the time being. Users can switch to the experimental branch by heading over to the settings page of their Control Center (in right corner of the settings page). â Their A321ceo and neo are available for $69.95 each + VAT on their website. entry.title: MOZA Releases New Flight Sim Equipment at the FSExpo 2025
entry.summary: Sim: OTHER. MOZA has recently launched a range of new products at FlightSimExpo 2025, further expanding its flight simulation ecosystem. Among these new products are a new force feedback flight base, a throttle quadrant, a pair of rudder pedals, and more. The first new release is the AB6 FFB Flight Base, accompanied by the MHG Flightstick. The AB6 Flight Base delivers 6 Nm of torque, providing realistic torque feedback due to its high-performance outrunner motor. It also includes dual throttle sliders. The MHG Flightstick, designed for high-performance control in conjunction with the AB6, is ergonomically crafted and features programmable buttons, hat switches, adjustable resistance, and more. Next, MOZA introduces the MTQ Throttle Quadrant. This new throttle quadrant is designed to be modular, ensuring compatibility for flying both commercial jets and fighter jets. It features swappable grips, allowing users to choose between fighter jet style levers, Airbus style levers, and Boeing style levers. The team has introduced a new pair of rudder pedals known as the MRP Rudder Pedals. These pedals are constructed entirely from metal and feature metal brake pedals as well. They come equipped with non-slip rubber pads for added stability. Designed for high performance, the pedals include a precision swing-arm design, customizable centering force, and an optional adjustable damper. The final release is the FMP18 Front Panel System. Inspired by legacy naval jet cockpits, this system offers a full-scale, cockpit-grade replica. It features authentic 7.1-inch square displays, universal VESA mount compatibility, and an angle adjustment clamp. This system is a must-have for anyone who enjoys these kinds of aircraft. MOZA has not yet announced pricing for its various products, but we will keep you updated once new information is available. â For the latest flight simulation news, remember to stay tuned on Threshold! â If you enjoy our content and want to support Threshold, consider joining us on Patreon!

entry.title: Parallel 42 Announce New Aircraft, Updates, at FSExpo 2025
entry.summary: Sim: FS24. The team at Parallel 42 recently made several announcements during #FSExpoFriday at FlightSimExpo 2025. Among these are an upcoming ChasePlane update, a new aircraft reveal, and more. The team began by discussing ChasePlane, which is celebrating its 8th anniversary this year, having first appeared during the FSX and P3D era. They shared several exciting new features that will be included in the next update for ChasePlane for Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020. These features include major refactoring, spot view adjustments, support for Tobii Eye Tracker, named shortcuts, custom cinematics, and much more. The upcoming update will be released through both a stable channel and an experimental channel, with the launch scheduled for next week. â Regarding compatibility with Microsoft Flight Simulator 2024, the team mentioned that they have an internal build that is currently functioning. Although the build requires some fine-tuning, it will be ready in due time. Once it is polished, it will be available through the experimental channel. The team has announced that they are currently working on making Flow compatible with Microsoft Flight SimulatorÂ 2024. Additionally, they are bringing sceneries from Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020 to 2024, including Bush Plane Campout and Mexican Mountain, which will be available in the coming weeks. Lastly, the team discussed the Super Patriot Mark II, FreedomFox, and Fox2 aircraft. The 3D design of the Super Patriot Mark II is entering its final stages, and this aircraft is being developed in partnership with Patriot Aircraft. Initially, the FreedomFox and Fox2 were intended to be compatible with the 2024 version, but they will now be developed natively for 2024 to some extent. While a complete overhaul is not planned, a significant update will be implemented. Additionally, the team announced a collaboration with Trent Palmer to bring the Legend Nomad to the simulator. entry.title: Navigraph Announcing Three New Features at the FSExpo 2025
entry.summary: Sim: OTHER. Navigraph recently took the stage during #FSExpoFriday at FlightSimExpo 2025. The team announced three exciting new features, including an agreement with Rogers Data, Taxiway Routing, and Simlink v2. Stephen announced that Navigraph has partnered with Rogers Data to provide VFR ICAO charts for all of Europe, free for all subscribers. In the second feature presentation, Alex took the stage to introduce Taxiway Routing. This new functionality enables users to select gates and intersections to plan a taxi route. Users have the option to either choose a route manually or allow the system to generate one automatically. Additionally, users can specify turns while navigating. There are also plans to introduce a variety of other features related to Taxiway Routing in the future. In the final feature announcement, Alex introduced Simlink V2. This new version will allow users to inject AI traffic into the Navigraph Charts App, providing native support for Microsoft Flight Simulator (MSFS), X-Plane (XP), and Prepar3D (P3D). Additionally, support for third-party integration with BeyondATC will be included. Furthermore, the update rate for aircraft position in the Navigraph Chart App will be quadrupled. entry.title: iniBuilds Releases Hamad International Airport and Doha Landmarks for MSFS 2024
entry.summary: Sim: FS24. iniBuilds has just launched its version of Hamad International Airport (OTHH) for Microsoft Flight Simulator 2024. In addition, the team has also released a Doha Landmarks package for the simulator. Each year, Hamad International Airport welcomes nearly 53 million passengers, making it one of the busiest airports in the Middle East. Opened in 2014, Hamad International Airport is still a relatively new facility, built to replace the over 70-year-old Doha International Airport. Since its inauguration, air traffic to and from Hamad International has steadily increased. Today, it serves as a hub for Qatar Airways, Qatar Airways Cargo, and Qatar Executive, while also accommodating a variety of other airlines, allowing for destinations around the globe. Last year, the airport recorded 279,000 aircraft movements and welcomed a total of 52.7 million passengers. The airport scenery features hand-made ground textures, true-to-life airport landside recreation, dynamic airport lighting, handcrafted HD jetways, and much more. The landmarks package includes over 30 iconic landmarks across Doha. The newly released Hamad International Airport is now available from iniBuilds for approximately $27.23. Additionally, the Doha Landmarks package is available from iniBuilds for approximately $13.61. Until July 4th, you can receive the Doha Landmarks package for free with the purchase of the Hamad International Airport. â For the latest flight simulation news, remember to stay tuned on Threshold! â If you enjoy our content and want to support Threshold, consider joining us on Patreon!

entry.title: FlightSim Studio Announcement and Development Update at the FSExpo 2025
entry.summary: Sim: FS24. During the #FSExpoFriday at FlightSimExpo 2025, the FlightSim Studio team announced a new expansion and provided a development update on several of their current projects. The team has announced a new expansion for its Boeing 727 series called the Super 27 Expansion. This expansion will introduce new engines, a digital vertical speed indicator (VSI), automatic spoilers, a moving map display, dual distance measuring equipment (DMEs), and more for both the freighter and passenger versions of the Boeing 727. The release is scheduled for late 2025. Additionally, the team mentioned that after launching the Super 27 Expansion, they will begin working on the Boeing 727-100 variant. The next item on the agenda was a development update for the E-Jets. The team presented a preview of the ongoing development, which includes a custom Flight Management System (FMS) featuring LNAV autopilot, vertical path calculation, and route drawing capabilities. This preview is anticipated to be released in 2025. Additionally, the team expects to begin VNAV testing later this year. To finish up, the team announced that a native version of the Tecnam for Microsoft Flight Simulator 2024 is expected in late 2025 or early 2026. We will keep you updated as soon as the team shares new information. â For the latest flight simulation news, remember to stay tuned on Threshold! â If you enjoy our content and want to support Threshold, consider joining us on Patreon!

entry.title: Contrail Announces FA50 for MSFS 2020/2024
entry.summary: Sim: FS24. At the #FSExpoFriday event during FlightSimExpo 2025, Contrail founder Lars Pinkenburg announced that the team is currently developing the FA50 for Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020 and 2024. This aircraft will be the first one developed in-house by Contrail. The Dassault Falcon 50, known for its tri-engine design, has been utilised by both private and military operators globally. This aircraft is certified to reach altitudes of up to 49,000 feet and is capable of flying both transcontinental and transoceanic routes. The addon will be equipped with fully customised avionics systems, including the GNSXLS Flight Management System, the Apollo MX20 MFD, the Collins Electronic Flight Information System suite, and a dedicated custom autopilot. Currently, the aircraft is set to feature 18 different liveries. While the price has not yet been determined, it is expected to be released in 2025. entry.title: iniBuilds Updates A350 Airliner for MSFS 2020/2024 with ULR Variant, Teases A340
entry.summary: Sim: FS24. iniBuilds has released version 1.1.0 of its A350 Airliner for Microsoft Flight Simulator 2024, bringing a raft of improvements and additions, including the long-awaited A350 ULR variant. The A350 ULR, or Ultra Long Range, features an increased maximum takeoff weight and fuel capacity, with a range of up to 9,700 nautical miles. Designed for non-stop, ultra-long-haul flights, it supports operations lasting over 19 hours, with Singapore Airlines operating the type exclusively, in a two-class, premium-heavy configuration. iniBuilds has adapted this layout for their ULR variant in MSFS 2024, bringing a reworked cabin and compatibility with FS24âs career mode, including interactive boarding procedures. Further additions include the integration of functional emergency evacuation slides and the PDOS (Power Door Opening System) for opening the engine cowlings. Performance has seen additional improvements, with reduced CPU load and a streamlined WASM structure. Furthermore, iniBuilds has overhauled the ECAM, refined the fly-by-wire system, and introduced several new FMS features, including Conditional Descent Advisory and Estimated Time to Target. The update also introduces support for iniBuilds' new modular cabin packs, a separately sold line of swappable, airline-specific interiors, providing realistic cabin layouts from carriers like Air France, Virgin Atlantic and Lufthansa. Artwork updates include refined nose cone shading, reworked cockpit sidesticks, adjusted camera positions, and cockpit storm lighting. iniBuilds has also integrated event-driven scenarios and confirmed upcoming support for a 3D HUD with dynamic projection and crosswind adaptation. Despite popular demand, 8x time compression remains unsupported, due to instability in the autopilot logic at high speeds. iniBuilds also affirmed their confidence in the aircraftâs flight model, citing validation through full-motion simulators, while noting user experience may vary depending on hardware. The developer recommends users apply a 1:1 axis curve for the most accurate control feel.Â â iniBuilds closed their post with a single teaser image of what appears to be an Airbus A340-300, possibly hinting at their next big project. As the A350 Airliner enters a more mature development phase, iniBuilds plans to space out future updates, while continuing work on feature enhancements and long-term refinements. â You can find the entry.title: Laminar Research Showcases X-Plane 12.3 Update at the FSExpo 2025
entry.summary: Sim: X-Plane. Laminar has during during #FSExpoFriday 2025 given an update on the future of X-Plane 12, with performance improvements, art upgrades, and major simulation system enhancements all in active development. The team confirmed that version 12.2.1 will enter public beta next Friday, while the highly anticipated 12.3.0 release will begin private beta testing the same day. â The presentation began with a recap of version 12.2, which is now publicly available. Key fixes and visual improvements include updated ground textures, revised lighting and atmospheric rendering, new aircraft braking effects, and a resolution to the long-standing dark cockpit issue, significantly improving visibility across default aircraft. Laminar also previewed upcoming additions to the X-Plane Gateway, with new community-driven assets currently in development. These include various fire trucks, police cars, construction vehicles, enhanced ramp lighting, and improved ground markings. Much of this work is being led by newly joined scenery artist Justin, also known as Mr. X, and the team highlighted the ability to customise ramps with new compass roses, labels, and colours. The upcoming 12.3.0 version will introduce a foundational shift in how X-Plane uses CPU resources. Laminar has confirmed that multi-core rendering is now in development, with a new job system already built to handle AI traffic, texture paging, and network synchronisation. Internal testing has demonstrated performance gains of up to 30% at graphically intensive airports, such as Frankfurt. Additional optimisation targets GPU and VRAM usage. Laminar is currently refining cloud rendering and night lighting processes, which should result in greater efficiency and reduced GPU workload, particularly beneficial for users running in 4K. Laminar is adopting new virtual memory techniques, to speed up texture loading and safely offload unused graphical assets. The default Airbus A330 is set for a major update, with reworked metallic surfaces, improved textures, detailed weathering and glare shield fixes. Furthermore, brake fire simulations, refined lighting and cabin ambience, dynamic passenger lighting, and altitude-aware illumination modes were also shown off. A major technical addition is a fully GPU-bound weather radar, integrated by default on the default Boeing 737-800, A330-300, MD-82, Cirrus Visionjet, Baron B58 and Citation X. The default weather radar includes manual tilt, ground clutter filtering, sector scanning, and predictive wind shear alerts. An API has been made available for third-party developers to integrate the feature into their products. â The G1000 avionics suite has also been upgraded, now featuring synthetic vision, rendered entirely on the GPU. This allows terrain, obstacle, and traffic overlays, including support for online networks like VATSIM and IVAO, without adding CPU overhead or impacting performance. Beyond the simulator core, Laminar reaffirmed progress on its new X-Plane Store. The backend now supports account-based logins and is integrating modern payment systems. â More details are expected as development on the 12.3.0 update continues. â For all the latest updates, be sure to follow Threshold! â If you enjoy our content and want to support Threshold, consider joining us on Patreon! â

entry.title: Drzewiecki Design Releases Western Sydney International Airport for MSFS 2020/2024
entry.summary: Sim: FS24. Drzewiecki Design has recently released its rendition of Western Sydney International Airport (YSWS) for Microsoft Flight Simulator 2020 and 2024. This airport is situated approximately 38 miles from the center of Sydney and is currently under construction, with a projected completion date at the end of 2026. Once finished, it will serve as a supplement to the existing Sydney Kingsford Smith Airport (YSSY). Construction of the new Western Sydney International Airport began in 2018 and is expected to be completed by late 2026. This airport will be notable for using a remote and virtual control tower rather than the traditional air traffic control tower, making it the first airport in Australia to feature this technology. The new airport is being built to supplement the existing Sydney Kingsford Smith Airport (YSSY), which has limited space for expansion. As of now, airlines including Qantas, Jetstar, and Singapore Airlines have announced plans to operate flights to the new airport. The new scenery includes an up-to-date and high-quality model of the airport, advanced night lighting, custom jetways, and many additional features. The newly released Western Sydney International Airport is now available from SimMarket for approximately $23.44. â For the latest flight simulation news, remember to stay tuned on Threshold! â If you enjoy our content and want to support Threshold, consider joining us on Patreon!
